I have discussed the matter with Isa and have told him to inform the Shaikhs that the pi'esents are on their way. All the Shaikhs except Has al Khaimah, who got as far as Dehai and would not come on hoard the ship, are due these presents. Dehai was not actually present hut did his hest to come and so could he included, more especially as I have just given him the 0.13.13. 2 . I helieve you have the hulk of the Bushire Toshakhana at Bahrain. Could you please pick out suitable presents from these and arrange to present them or have them presented as soon as possible as coming from me. I should like the presents to he pretty good ones, so if what you have does not appear to he up to the mark let me know. I could authorise you to make suitable purchases in Bahrain. The following is the list of recipients as given by Isa. 1. Shaikh of Dehai. 2. Shaikh of Sharjah. 5. Shaikh of Umm-al-Qawain. 4. Shaikh of Ahu Dhabi 5. March »■ 193 Dear Sir, s We duly received your esteemed letter No.324/17/1 dated 27th February» and have to thank you for your instruction to supply various Firearms and Ammunition. two of the 9«5 nun. B.S.A. Sporting Magazine Rifles in stock, and the manufacturers are unable to guarantee delivery of the remaining three in less than from six to eight weeks. We therefore propose to ship by the next available Steamer all the weapons which we can supply immediately from stock, as we notice you write by Air Mail, and presume that you would like delivery at the earliest possible moment, and the balance of the order will follow as sqon as we the remaining three B.S.A. Magazine Rifles. With reference to your instruction to supply F .380 Webley & Scott Auto. Pistols II.P. Finish, you no doubt recollect that in our letter No. G.D. 5534 uaueu 23rd August, 1934* we advised you that the manufacturers have discontinued to make this particular model, and it is noY/ extremely difficult to obtain these weapons, either new or second-hand. We have again made full enquiries on your behalf, from practically every dealer in this country, and we have only been successful in obtaining one new model, Nickel Plated finish, price £2 11s. Od., / and one second-hand blued finish price £2 3 s. Od., which/ we are forv/arding to you, and we trust our action v^ill * meet v/ith your approval. We regret to state that it is absolutely impossible for us to secure any more of these Pistols in .380 calibre, but we can of course supply you with the .32 Pistols, of the same make at £2 Os. Od. each,! and perhaps you would kindly let us know if you are prepared to accept this calibre* but it Yfill of course be necessary for you to order a supply of the .32 calibre ammunition. With regard to item (1) at the moment we only have P.T.O^\ : r — - «**• - ii iiflltfefc - 2 - If you would prefer all the pistols to fire the same cartridges, we can supply you with the ^380 Browning Auto. Pistols at £3 5§ .» Od. for the new models, or Od. second-hand, hut these are of Belgian make, and the Wehley & Scott Pistols are the only British weapons are on the market. When favouring us with your instructions regarding the balance of the tv/o automatic pistols to complete your order, would you kindly let us knoYr if it is essential that the weapons should he supplied in the nickel plated finish, as there are very few N.P. pistols in stock, either new or second-hand, and it is much easier to obtain early delivery of the blued models. With regard to item ( 6 ) we notice you mention ’’double' barrel folding hammerless gun with safety catch .MO bore at £3 Os. Od., whereas if you will kindly refer to pur letter No^G-*D. 0915> dated 8 th February, 1933, you will note that the weapon quoted at this price is a single barrel gun. We therefore presume that ’’double’’ is a typing error, and are accordingly supplying a single barrel gun at £3 Os. Od.*and hope this will be in order. ' The three 12 bore Guns and all the ammunition can be supplied immediately from stock* The only items remaining to complete'your-order will be the three B.S.A. Magazine Rifles, and two automatic pistols, and when favouring us with your instructions regarding the Pistols, we should be grateful if you would please let us have another ”No Objection Certificate’’ for these items, as the certificate enclosed with your letter now under reply will have to go forward with the first consignment, and formal advice of despatch will in due course be -sent you by our Shipping Department# Awaiting your reply, and assuring you at all times of our best attention,- • • We are, Sir, Yours faithfully, K PiMRPPPPiPIIBy Air Mail #' Ho» 17/14. The risk under this policy attaches from the time the goods are removed from the place of storage at the place of shipment for conveyance on the insured voyage. Termination of Risk. The risk terminates immediately the goods are delivered at destination to the place deter mined by the consignees for their storage (place of final delivery). a) Sea Port. When the destination to which the goods are insured is a sea port, the risk terminates not later than after the expiration of twenty days from the day the goods are landed at destination. b) Inland Place. 1) When the destination to which the goods are insured is a place inland, the risk ter minates not later than after the expiration of 10 days from the day the goods are discharged or unloaded during the ordinary course of transit at destination. 2) If the assured or the consignee cause or are responsible for any delay in the con veyance of the goods after their landing at the sea port until their arrival at destination, the risk terminates from the commencement of such delay, but not before the voyage would have been completed in the normal course of events. Any loss or damage to be assessed without delay. Ad a) and b). The insurer is entitled to an additional premium to be agreed in case of an unusual delay occurring in the landing of the goods after their discharge from the sea-going vessel. Extension of periods Covered by this Policy. Against an additional premium of at least Vie th per cent for every further 20 days, and against further additional premium for risks specially included in the main Policy (e. g. Breakage, Leakage, War) extensions may be granted for 1. the periods determined sub a) and b) 2. the policy in case of delay b 3 ) after landing at the sea port until arrival at destination, at the same time as the declaration on the policy is made or after such declaration in extraordinary cases, but only before the expiry of the declared period. Within these periods, which must not be exceeded, the consignee is at liberty to delay the conveyance of the goods. Warehouse to Warehouse Clause II (with limited liability guaranteed after landing). (See also Tariff.) The following warehouse to warehouse clause only applies if specially agreed upon. Commencement of Risk, The risk under this policy attaches from the time the goods are removed from the place of storage at the place of shipment for conveyance on the insured voyage. Termination of Risk. The risk terminates immediately the goods are delivered at destination to the place deter mined by the consignee for their storage (place of final delivery), but in no event later than after the expiration of . . days from the day of landing of the goods at the sea port. No ex tension of time is admissible under this clause. Within this period of time, which must not be exceeded, the consignee is at liberty to delay the conveyance of the goods between the lan ding at the sea port and the place of final delivery at destination. Any loss or damage to be assessed without delay. The insurer is entitled to an additional premium to be arranged in case of an unusual delay occurring in the landing of the goods after their discharge from the sea-going vessel. If a delay of more than 20 days after landing of the goods at the sea port is agreed upon, an additional premium of at least Vie th per cent is payable for every further 20 days applied for. A further additional premium is to be agreed upon to cover risks specially included in the main Policy (e.g. Breakage, Leakage, War).Nord-Deutsche Vars.G-es., Hamburg Allianz cl Stuttgarter Verein V.A.G-., Berlin Ailingia Vers.A.ti-.^ Hamburg 60 i* t 20 io 20 /a 100 jo i *c; - x '• ■ Li B • , . City Office: 9 & IO.Bond Court, WALBROOK.e.c.*. 26 th January, 1937 With further reference to our letter dated 18th instant regarding the seven Rifles which we have been instructed to despatch to you by The Political Resident in The Persian Gulf, we have just heard that the weapons are now ready for despatch at the Works, and we are therefore requesting our Shipping Department to give the necessary forwarding instructions, and they will in due course send you full advice as to the route and method of shipment. > We would explain that the Rifles and Ammunition are being despatched from the Continent to save as much time as possible, as there would only be additional delay if these goods are imported and re-exported from England, and for this reason the Rifle Cases, which are being sent from this country, have been supplied with loose blocks, and it will be quite an easy matter for these blocks to be cut down to the required length so that the barrels and stocks are kept in correct position. The blocks have been purposely left on the long side, as it is naturally easier to cut them down than to add to their length. Assuring you at all times of our best attention, V/e are, Sir, Yours faithfully,,J':. fe ' No. 408-17/14 Political Agency, Bahrain, the 17th February 1937 To \M<n&T>ifl-T£ Messrs F.P. Baker and Company Limited 2, Upper James Street, Golden Square, Regent Street, LONDON. Dear Sirs With reference to your letter No. 0091 dated the 26th January 1937 about the despatch of seven rifles and ammunition to me, I should be obliged if you would let me know by telegram in what ship and on what date the consignment may be expected to reach Bahrain. To save expense it v/ill be sufficient if you will telegraph deferred:- M Political Bahrain. (Name of steamer) (month) (date of month on which consignment is expected at Bahrain)” five words in all. Yours faithfully, Lieutenant-Colonel Political Agent, BahrainIS' No enquiry respecting this Telegram can be attended to without the production of this Copy. Printed in England. (Feb. 1932.) Office of tne Political Kesident D.O.flQ.g/642 in the Persian uulf ? Camp, Bahrain. Dated tne 14tn September, 1936. Dear Sir Trenchard Thank you for your lettet of the 27th August 1938 about presents for the Trucial Coast Shaikhs to be purchased from Toshakhana Funds. I enclose herewith a copy of tne proposals which 1 sent in at the beginning of July 1938, and I understand that there is a total of Rs.4000/- available for Toshakhana Expenditure. 2® We did have a talk about this before you went on leave, but at that time you said that you would consider my proposals after your return to Bushire. If, however, you think that the enclosed suggestions are sound, you might perhaps consider buying the rifles and ammunition before you leave England, though the radio sets would probably be cheaper in Bahrain than in London as tney are of American manufacture. Yours sincerely, ed. h.Weightman. Memorandum . ?»'-****»** ... * m*- k.;. m*> We have been experiencing some difficulty in finding somebody trained to clean and oil our Toshakhana arms and ammunition. The rifles cleaned by the Police guard have not bee: altogether satisfactory and I wonder if it woul be possible for one of your Indian Havildars to call at the Agency twice a month, say on the first and 16th, and have the Agency arms and ammunition cleaned under his supervision by the police guard. 2 . In case this is possible, I would lik< to pay some monthly remuneration to the Havilda say Rs.10/- p.m., or to the Bahrain Government for utilizing the services of their employees. Major, Political Agent, Bahrain.No. /3/^- f/? of 1560 Office of the Adviser to the Grovernment, Bahrain Dated, 29th J/Thani 1360 July 23, 1941. His Britannic Majesty^ Political Agent, Bahrain. Memorandum:- Reference your memorandum No. 1377-17/14 dated 18th July 1941. I shall be pleased to make arrangements for one of the Indian Instructors to call twice monthly at the Agency on 1st and 16th of every month in order to supervise the cleaning of the Agency rifles. I suggest that the N.C.O. in question, Havildar Nadhir Khan, should be paid Rs. 5/- per month for performing this duty. I will instruct him to commence from 1 st August. I have asked Khan Sahib * Abdur Razzaq about the question of 1-116 Hon ’ 1:le tiAe Political Resident giving presents to -the shaikhs here when he tours on the Trucial Coast in March next* You asked me «bout it when I passed through Bahrain on my way to Basrah* The Residency -Agent's opinion is that it would create a good impression 5 if the Political Resident gave presents on his first tour; the most suitable, in fact, the only suitable, presents are rifles, shot-guns and binoculars in that order; ail presents should be the same unless it is wished to differentiate between the recipients; at least IOC rounds of ammunition should be given with a rifle or gun* It is better to give nothing than to depast from the standard here advaneed| If it is not possible or thought proper to give expensive presents to all the Shaikhs at this time^they may be given, as Major Alban opin^ed, in recognition of special service; and for this reason at the moment no presents are required* I agree with this opinion. B.Wakefield,Esquire,I.C, olitical Agent, Bahrain <>D.O. No. C/188 Dated the 9th February 1942, C * V/hile I was passing through Bushire on my way here you asked me to make inquiries about the presents which it would be suitable for you to give during your projected tour of the Trucial Coast in March# 2. Alban told me that it was by no means an invariable custom for the Political Resident to give presents to the Shaikhs, and he was opposed to the giving of presents becoming a normal or routine practice. He expressed the view that presents should be given primarily to signify recognition of special services rendered by particular individuals. He considered that the most suitable presents were rifles, field- glasses or pistols. 3. Later I had a chance of seeing Felly (who flew to Basra for a couple of days in a Royal Air Force machine for urgent dental treatment), and asked him to let me have his views after consulting the Residency Agent. I enclose a copy of his letter of 4th February. ! 4. I am in substantial agreement with what Felly writes - especially with his view that no present is better than a present which does not come up to the expected standard of munificence. A good present (if you are in a position to supply one l) has, I think, been earned by the Shaikh of Sharjah for his assistance in the activities of the Royal Air Force; and I am hoping, as I write, that Dubai will also qualify in the same manner for a reward. 5 . I don’t think I can usefully add anything further, as Alban and Khan Sahib Abdur Razzaq have much greater experience than I have of such matters. There are now no regular Amirs-i-Saifeh. Oneor the gold watches proposed for them should, I suggest be given to Abdulla bin Paris, the Shaikh*s secretary. Ml *t ht 331 The head farrash has never handled a rifle or gun and even if he is trained I think he would still he useless. / We have no material to clean t he arms and ammunition and so far we have been borrowing from the Port. I suggest that we ask the Superintendent of Police to send his Indian Havildar twice a month to the Agency, on the 1st and 15th of each month, to have the arms cleaned by the police guard under his supervision. I could hand over the guns in the morning and then lock up before the office closes. In this way there would be no fear of loss. 7e could pay the Havildar for his services. As he would be cleaning the Bushire Toshakhana arms and ammunition also, we could divide the payment fequally between Bahrain and Bushire. I think it would be not much inconvenience for the Havildar to attend to this twice a month, and when the arms have once been thoroughly cleaned and oiled he may then come only once a month say on the 1 st. Without his supervision the local police would not be able to clean them properly. The guns that were sent to Qatar were at least 10 times cleaned by the police and once by Mohsin, but still it appears the Defence Officer is complaining that the two of them which were returned to him by P.C.L. as unserviceable, were still rusted from some places. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 17/14 I Toshakhana Articles for Bushire Correspondence regarding.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 337; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. Two additional foliation sequences are present in parallel between ff 3-303 and ff 305-316; these numbers are written in pencil, but are not circled (except for a number of circled numbers which have been crossed out).

mods.abstract: The file is concerned with the Bushire Residency [Persian Gulf Political Residency] Toshakhana — a store of gifts kept with the Bahrain Political Agency, so that they would be available for presentation to the Trucial Coast Shaikhs when needed. Regular stock accounts are submitted to Bushire to keep the Residency updated on the number and range of articles being held on its behalf. The bulk of the file is concerned with the acquisition of new articles for the Bushire Toshakhana; the purchase of weapons and ammunition makes up almost the entirety of these purchases. The file therefore contains supporting correspondence, invoices, payment receipts, as well as export licenses and 'No Objection Certificates' to facilitate the export of weaponry. The principal suppliers are F P Baker and Company Limited and Suleman Omer and Company, Karachi.Also contained in the file is correspondence between British officials in the Persian Gulf; this correspondence is either concerned with new acquisitions for the Toshakhana, the transfer of articles between agencies, or making arrangements for presenting gifts to the various Shaikhs of the Trucial Coast. The main corresponding officials are the Political Agent, Bahrain (Charles Geoffrey Prior, Percy Gordon Loch, and Tom Hickinbotham); the Political Resident, Persian Gulf (Trenchard Craven Fowle and Hugh Weightman); the Secretary to the Political Resident; the Residency Agent, Sharjah; and the Trucial Coast Political Agent.Also within the file is an exchange from July 1941 (folios 249-251) between the Bahrain Political Agent and Charles Belgrave, Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, regarding arrangements for cleaning the weaponry stored in the Toshakhana.The Arabic language content consists of a couple of letters (folios 43-44 and folio 60) with English translation from the Bahrain Political Agent to the Residency Agent, Sharjah, as well as five letters (folios 45-50) from the Political Agent presenting gifts to various Trucial Coast Shaikhs; their translated replies in English can be found on folios 70-75.

name.namePart: Secretary to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf
